The Way of the Coder

How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love Coding.

Without any idea where to begin or what I needed to code, I knew coding was the path for me. So I got some tips on where to start. I downloaded Intellij and started coding in Java. In the beginning I did some simple tutorials, then I started taking online courses, but class work is really not my bag of chips as they say. I can't just sit and listen to a person who tells me how it should work. I rather just figure it out for myself, create my personal techniques, and go as fast or slow as I want.

Therefore I began by thinking about what kind of game I could make. A simple game for a n00b coder. So I made a snake game and a Super Mario Bros clone and many more. But it was not challenging enough and I alreay wanted more.

I always loved the mysteries of the universe. I love science fiction movies. So why not make a space game. Where I can fly with a space ship and see distance stars and meet new species. This would mean I would have to think long and hard about how to set up a game like that. What was needed? How do I seperate one thing from another. Is a asteroid the same "object" as a space ship? What would the rules of the game be? Do I make something that should be popular or something that is unique?

My philosophy background came in handy here, to think of an object as a duality would become a smart choice later on in the development of the game. So I started by making physical objects and characters. A character would be the brain, and the object the body of a thing in the game, something that could collide with something else for instance. But if I have two different things, they have to be differently implemented within the game. And so, a game and space engine were created. The game engine to keep track of characters that are added to the game (and much more later on) and the space engine that would handle physics and everything else that is important for a physical object.

Then came the behaviors of characters and scenarios for the game. Behaviors handle the way an object moves and reacts towards other objects. Scenarios handle what happens in the whole of space. Particularly this part of the game would become difficult, but ultimately it worked exactly how I wanted it too (well, maybe not exactly).

Now it was time for some change and to see how fast I could make something new. Something from scratch, but with a time table. That became the half year of pumping out game after game, most of them half finished, but my coding skills were being tested and those skills became more apparent. I could see that I was getting much better, very fast.

So I returned to my cruel mistress of the night, my space game. There it lay, with a smile that told me: "I am way too good for you, and I will always laugh at you, but you keep coming back." But I knew I could tame this wild beast that I created. And so, I began again. Familiarizing myself with my own code, shaking my head often when I saw how badly I did some things. I started fixing bugs, smacking exception after exception to the curb, and little by little it became a game.

Now I am working on the server side of things, which is a new chapter in my evolution in the way of the coder. But this is just another obstacle in my search of true enlightenment. All I am saying is that in the last two and a half years, this guy in his thirties, just started teaching himself a skill that is useful anywhere. The skill of the future! Something that will be taught to our children in elementary schools in a couple of years (I hope). In conclusion: You are never too old to start learning.
